Weird to think that it is only now that I'm associating a face, a life, to the names that I continuously had to deal with in my undergraduate years and now while I approach the end of my masters. Neyman being afraid of Fisher's criticisms, Egon Pearson establishing his own journal for fear of angering his father Karl by working with Neyman on Fisher's idea of the likelihood function and developing the theory of hypothesis testing. Fisher moving from being the lowly genius marked by its then tyrant Karl Pearson into being its own feared but at the same time revered tyrant.I did find problems in Salsburg's unwillingness to invoke even a single line of mathematical complexity into the book, which results in him trailing off into other topics just when his discussion of a particular development hits full stride. But alas, this is a book written for the nonmathematicians, and to that end, certain tradeoffs must be made. It certainly did not affect my enjoyment of the book. A week from starting it and I come out with a relived appreciation for the field I've committed myself into, and to the men and women who built its foundations. This is a book that I highly recommend for young statisticians, and those who are considering statistics as a prospective field of study.

The lives of the great 20th Century statisticians! What could be more engrossing than a hagiography of bean counters?I read this book because I have a vague interest in statistics, but a very poor foundation for grappling with the actual math. If I've taken away an appreciation for the concepts that have driven the remarkable "statistical revolution" that I, like most readers, was not aware that we have just experienced, it's at an entirely subconscious level. I'm sure I can't now expound wisely on the usefulness and pitfalls of P-values, or explain non-Bayesian vs. Bayesian approaches. Thanks to this surprisingly readable, if appropriately non-exciting history, perhaps I'll be able to get a little traction next time I try to tread that territory.To Salsburg's credit, it was not actually boring, given that the "action" described was the presentation of papers at conventions, or the inclusion of names in bibliographies. I've developed a pretty high tolerance for the prosaic, however, so no promises.Recommended audience: students of statistics who want to know more about their heroes; people like me who will pick up anything from the "light science" shelf in the library and, once committed, stick with it out of pride, or for the heck of it.Favorite fact: (spoiler alert) Some of the great advances in modern statistics were made on behalf of the Guinness brewery, in their continuing effort to improve and maintain the consistency of their tasty, tasty beverage.

A seemingly thorough overview of the history of statistics and the various people in it, but there are so many names and characters whizzing by that sometimes the statistics itself is left behind. There are several times where the author mentions an important theory or development, only to give it the barest explanation, or none at all. Understandably this is not a book about statistics itself, and to attempt to satisfactorily explain and prove the broad collection of ideas within it would likely require multiple volumes.  The book at its best in the beginning, before branching off in every which way, when examining the very beginning of the field, with Gosset and Pearson and Fisher. As it continues, and more and more characters are introduced, it becomes difficult to keep track of the landscape, or of a strong logical flow to the arrangement of chapters. For a person already familiar with some of the history of statistics or with the theory itself this may be fine, but for a relative neophytes like myself it makes for a more difficult read.  Despite its flaws, the book is still interesting and coherent enough to be worth the read, though some later chapters are skippable.

This book is an informal history of the development of statistics in the 20th century. The author, who was a statistician in the pharmaceutical industry, had meant many of the statisticians whose work he discusses. It is not a mathematical book, in the sense that not a line of algebra is to be found in it.  The author begins with Karl Pearson in Britain at the begining of the twentieth century, when he took over Francis Galton (cousin of Charles Darwin, promoter of the use of fingerprints in identification, and eugenicist) biometrical (measuring people) laboratory in London. Pearson believed that the aim of science, in a world where the objects of study show ubiquitous numerical variation in the measurement of any trait you care to mention, should be the determination of the smaller number of parameters (numbers like the average, the standard deviation, plus some more obscure ones like symmetry and kurtosis) that describe the distribution of variability of a trait. Pearson's importance was greatly inhanced by his ediotrial control over an important scientific journal, Biometrika  In this journal, Pearson early on published the work of William Gosset, the developer of a most useful statisticial test called the t test, with which one can determine how likely it is that two different samples with different means are in fact different. Gosset had to published under a pen name because his employer, the Guiness brewery, forbade its employees to publish after an unfortunate incident when a brewer gave out some trade secrets.  The next great figure, definitely of the most important statisticians, possibly the most important, and scientists of the 20th century was R. A. Fisher. Fisher developed most of the statistical techniques, such as analysis of variance, that I used 80 years later to analyze, interpret, and design experiments. Fisher combined great mathematical insight with the writing of a book,  Statistical Methods for Research Workers , that showed us lesser mortals how to go about designing and analyzing experiments in a proper manner without worrying us about how these methods worked. Unfortunately for proper mathematicians, he was less good in explaining in his other publications how he derived his methods, and in some cases I gather he never published any derivation. However his unpublished papers show he wasn't making it all up, indeed as late as the 1970s those who examined his unpublished work learned new insights. Gradually other math types filled in or found on their own the detailed proofs.  The other candidate for worlds greatest statistician would be A. N. Kolmogorov, who put probability on a firm mathematical foundation (among many other things). As this work is a necessary condition for statistical application to be valid, this is very important. He was also an important developer of statistical methods. Kolomogorov was a Soviet citizen of astonishingly wide interests (he spent a good deal of time teaching gifted children at a special Moscow school), and great kindness.  The third most important statistician would probably be Jerzy Neyman, a man of Polish antecedents who spent much of his career in the United States. Neyman, along with Egon Pearson (Karl's son) was the developer of the now ubiqutious notion of hypothesis testing. Neyman also developed the concept of a confidence interval. In hypothesis testing you determine how often an experimental outcome, called the null hypothesis, would occur do to chance alone. If this probability is below a small but arbitrary value, one concludes that the null hypothesis is rejected, and that the alternative hypothesis is correct. An example of confidence intervals is when a poll's results state that the president's approval rate is 45%, plus or minus 3%, with 95% confidence. Both of these ideas are controversial as well as very commonly used, in part because their meaning in application (the math is perfectly rigorous)becomes less clear the more you examine them.  Besides the greats, the author covers many other people (including John Tukey, who probably should be included in the list of greats), who made important contributions to statistics. He also covers other techniques than the ones I mentioned above, such as experimental design, non-parametric statistics, computer intensive methods such as the bootstrap, and Bayesian statistics.  The author also brings up the philosophical matters that continue to bedevil statistics, such as the meaning of a probability. The most common approach is the frequentist school, in which a probability is the fraction of total outcomes in which a particular outcome (say winning the lottery divided by the number of tickets you've bought) is observed. There are difficulties with this approach, as there are with alternative Bayesian approaches. I think the author is mistaken in his apparent belief that issue is primarily limited to applications of statistics; I would says that it is problem with all forms of knowledge which depend to some extent on induction, the drawing of conclusions from necessarily limited numbers of experiences.  The book includes a bibliography, including a most helpful annotated section of recommended books that are light on the math. There is also a chronology of developments in statistics.  I enjoyed the book. I found some of the discussions of statistical issues unclear, which I attribute to the author's unwillingness to introduce any mathematical notation in order to avoid scaring off readers. I think a little math at the level of simple algebra, possibly separated from the main text in separate boxes so as not to disturb the flow of the narrative, would have been helpful in this regard.

This book is a wonderful history of statistics. Salsburg does an excellent job of providing a truly human history of the names and methods we have all become so familiar with. This is not, however, a book of mathematical theory. Still, in his conclusion, Salsburg provides a brief overview of the epistemological problems associated with our interpretation of probability, enough so to make me think more about how I sling around P values as a researcher. More than anything, this book made me appreciate how hard it once was to actually calculate statistics, something that computers have certainly made us take for granted. This book should be required reading for first year graduate students in the physical and life sciences.

If you expect a solid overview about the history of statistics, this book is not for you. It's definitely not academic/encyclopedic. Salsburg provides a lot of anecdotes from his personal encounters with prominent statisticians. It is rather a story of statistical revolution as it as happening from its active participant and practitioner who helped to form its trajectory. The book is easy to read and entertaining. I personally enjoyed the chapters on problem solving, i.e. those that described how certain statistical procedures were developed in response to concrete problems one faced (aka Fisher's ANOVA and his crop studies, Student's t-test and his brewing problem, Chester Bliss's probit model as an answer to toxicology problem, etc)

A great book that takes you in a historical and biographical tour, from Pearson's and his skew distributions to Tukey's and his bootstraps (1895 -2000's), in a very fluid, interesting and easy to grasp manner. The final remarks of the book are for me the intellectually most important part of the book. As makes clear the importance of statistics in our every day but remark the problems that statistics face in a philosophical and ultimately scientifical manner.Notes: The book does not go deep into mathematical explanations but requires a deep interest and basic knowledge of statistics from the reader.

The Lady Tasting Tea is an entertaining history of mathematical statistics from its beginnings with the work of Karl Pearson to about the late eighties. More a collection of vignettes about different statisticians than a comprehensive history, the book has its best moments in the anecdotal description of its subjects, often drawing from Salsburg's own experience with them. While the book is written for non-experts, I am wondering how much a reader without a background in statistics will understand: The explanations are often more allusions to than descriptions of the innovations discussed. Having an interest in the field, though, the book humanises a lot of the great names in statistics.

Honestly, I am lukewarm on this book. It was interesting, and the subject matter is so impactful, I wanted to love it.However, I found it lacking both in math (some times you just need math - i get that the author wanted to make it accessible to everyone, but, sometimes the concepts just weren't clear enough without), and in narrative structure. The book jumped around a little bit, and occasionally it was challenging to follow a thread.The author's love for the subject matter and the subjects was quite clear, though.

I ate through this book like a fever - a particularly terminal one. Weird to think that it is only now that I'm associating a face, a life, to the names that I continuously had to deal with in my undergraduate years and now while I approach the end of my masters. Neyman being afraid of Fisher's criticisms, Egon Pearson establishing his own journal for fear of angering his father Karl by working with Neyman on Fisher's idea of the likelihood function and developing the theory of hypothesis testing. Fisher moving from being the lowly genius marked by its then tyrant Karl Pearson into being its own feared but at the same time revered tyrant.I did find problems in Salsburg's unwillingness to invoke even a single line of mathematical complexity into the book, which results in him trailing off into other topics just when his discussion of a particular development hits full stride. But alas, this is a book written for the nonmathematicians, and to that end, certain tradeoffs must be made. It certainly did not affect my enjoyment of the book. A week from starting it and I come out with a relived appreciation for the field I've committed myself into, and to the men and women who built its foundations. This is a book that I highly recommend for young statisticians, and those who are considering statistics as a prospective field of study.

The lives of the great 20th Century statisticians! What could be more engrossing than a hagiography of bean counters?I read this book because I have a vague interest in statistics, but a very poor foundation for grappling with the actual math. If I've taken away an appreciation for the concepts that have driven the remarkable "statistical revolution" that I, like most readers, was not aware that we have just experienced, it's at an entirely subconscious level. I'm sure I can't now expound wisely on the usefulness and pitfalls of P-values, or explain non-Bayesian vs. Bayesian approaches. Thanks to this surprisingly readable, if appropriately non-exciting history, perhaps I'll be able to get a little traction next time I try to tread that territory.To Salsburg's credit, it was not actually boring, given that the "action" described was the presentation of papers at conventions, or the inclusion of names in bibliographies. I've developed a pretty high tolerance for the prosaic, however, so no promises.Recommended audience: students of statistics who want to know more about their heroes; people like me who will pick up anything from the "light science" shelf in the library and, once committed, stick with it out of pride, or for the heck of it.Favorite fact: (spoiler alert) Some of the great advances in modern statistics were made on behalf of the Guinness brewery, in their continuing effort to improve and maintain the consistency of their tasty, tasty beverage.

A seemingly thorough overview of the history of statistics and the various people in it, but there are so many names and characters whizzing by that sometimes the statistics itself is left behind. There are several times where the author mentions an important theory or development, only to give it the barest explanation, or none at all. Understandably this is not a book about statistics itself, and to attempt to satisfactorily explain and prove the broad collection of ideas within it would likely require multiple volumes.  The book at its best in the beginning, before branching off in every which way, when examining the very beginning of the field, with Gosset and Pearson and Fisher. As it continues, and more and more characters are introduced, it becomes difficult to keep track of the landscape, or of a strong logical flow to the arrangement of chapters. For a person already familiar with some of the history of statistics or with the theory itself this may be fine, but for a relative neophytes like myself it makes for a more difficult read.  Despite its flaws, the book is still interesting and coherent enough to be worth the read, though some later chapters are skippable.

This book is an informal history of the development of statistics in the 20th century. The author, who was a statistician in the pharmaceutical industry, had meant many of the statisticians whose work he discusses. It is not a mathematical book, in the sense that not a line of algebra is to be found in it.  The author begins with Karl Pearson in Britain at the begining of the twentieth century, when he took over Francis Galton (cousin of Charles Darwin, promoter of the use of fingerprints in identification, and eugenicist) biometrical (measuring people) laboratory in London. Pearson believed that the aim of science, in a world where the objects of study show ubiquitous numerical variation in the measurement of any trait you care to mention, should be the determination of the smaller number of parameters (numbers like the average, the standard deviation, plus some more obscure ones like symmetry and kurtosis) that describe the distribution of variability of a trait. Pearson's importance was greatly inhanced by his ediotrial control over an important scientific journal, Biometrika  In this journal, Pearson early on published the work of William Gosset, the developer of a most useful statisticial test called the t test, with which one can determine how likely it is that two different samples with different means are in fact different. Gosset had to published under a pen name because his employer, the Guiness brewery, forbade its employees to publish after an unfortunate incident when a brewer gave out some trade secrets.  The next great figure, definitely of the most important statisticians, possibly the most important, and scientists of the 20th century was R. A. Fisher. Fisher developed most of the statistical techniques, such as analysis of variance, that I used 80 years later to analyze, interpret, and design experiments. Fisher combined great mathematical insight with the writing of a book,  Statistical Methods for Research Workers , that showed us lesser mortals how to go about designing and analyzing experiments in a proper manner without worrying us about how these methods worked. Unfortunately for proper mathematicians, he was less good in explaining in his other publications how he derived his methods, and in some cases I gather he never published any derivation. However his unpublished papers show he wasn't making it all up, indeed as late as the 1970s those who examined his unpublished work learned new insights. Gradually other math types filled in or found on their own the detailed proofs.  The other candidate for worlds greatest statistician would be A. N. Kolmogorov, who put probability on a firm mathematical foundation (among many other things). As this work is a necessary condition for statistical application to be valid, this is very important. He was also an important developer of statistical methods. Kolomogorov was a Soviet citizen of astonishingly wide interests (he spent a good deal of time teaching gifted children at a special Moscow school), and great kindness.  The third most important statistician would probably be Jerzy Neyman, a man of Polish antecedents who spent much of his career in the United States. Neyman, along with Egon Pearson (Karl's son) was the developer of the now ubiqutious notion of hypothesis testing. Neyman also developed the concept of a confidence interval. In hypothesis testing you determine how often an experimental outcome, called the null hypothesis, would occur do to chance alone. If this probability is below a small but arbitrary value, one concludes that the null hypothesis is rejected, and that the alternative hypothesis is correct. An example of confidence intervals is when a poll's results state that the president's approval rate is 45%, plus or minus 3%, with 95% confidence. Both of these ideas are controversial as well as very commonly used, in part because their meaning in application (the math is perfectly rigorous)becomes less clear the more you examine them.  Besides the greats, the author covers many other people (including John Tukey, who probably should be included in the list of greats), who made important contributions to statistics. He also covers other techniques than the ones I mentioned above, such as experimental design, non-parametric statistics, computer intensive methods such as the bootstrap, and Bayesian statistics.  The author also brings up the philosophical matters that continue to bedevil statistics, such as the meaning of a probability. The most common approach is the frequentist school, in which a probability is the fraction of total outcomes in which a particular outcome (say winning the lottery divided by the number of tickets you've bought) is observed. There are difficulties with this approach, as there are with alternative Bayesian approaches. I think the author is mistaken in his apparent belief that issue is primarily limited to applications of statistics; I would says that it is problem with all forms of knowledge which depend to some extent on induction, the drawing of conclusions from necessarily limited numbers of experiences.  The book includes a bibliography, including a most helpful annotated section of recommended books that are light on the math. There is also a chronology of developments in statistics.  I enjoyed the book. I found some of the discussions of statistical issues unclear, which I attribute to the author's unwillingness to introduce any mathematical notation in order to avoid scaring off readers. I think a little math at the level of simple algebra, possibly separated from the main text in separate boxes so as not to disturb the flow of the narrative, would have been helpful in this regard.

This book is a wonderful history of statistics. Salsburg does an excellent job of providing a truly human history of the names and methods we have all become so familiar with. This is not, however, a book of mathematical theory. Still, in his conclusion, Salsburg provides a brief overview of the epistemological problems associated with our interpretation of probability, enough so to make me think more about how I sling around P values as a researcher. More than anything, this book made me appreciate how hard it once was to actually calculate statistics, something that computers have certainly made us take for granted. This book should be required reading for first year graduate students in the physical and life sciences.

If you expect a solid overview about the history of statistics, this book is not for you. It's definitely not academic/encyclopedic. Salsburg provides a lot of anecdotes from his personal encounters with prominent statisticians. It is rather a story of statistical revolution as it as happening from its active participant and practitioner who helped to form its trajectory. The book is easy to read and entertaining. I personally enjoyed the chapters on problem solving, i.e. those that described how certain statistical procedures were developed in response to concrete problems one faced (aka Fisher's ANOVA and his crop studies, Student's t-test and his brewing problem, Chester Bliss's probit model as an answer to toxicology problem, etc)

A great book that takes you in a historical and biographical tour, from Pearson's and his skew distributions to Tukey's and his bootstraps (1895 -2000's), in a very fluid, interesting and easy to grasp manner. The final remarks of the book are for me the intellectually most important part of the book. As makes clear the importance of statistics in our every day but remark the problems that statistics face in a philosophical and ultimately scientifical manner.Notes: The book does not go deep into mathematical explanations but requires a deep interest and basic knowledge of statistics from the reader.

The Lady Tasting Tea is an entertaining history of mathematical statistics from its beginnings with the work of Karl Pearson to about the late eighties. More a collection of vignettes about different statisticians than a comprehensive history, the book has its best moments in the anecdotal description of its subjects, often drawing from Salsburg's own experience with them. While the book is written for non-experts, I am wondering how much a reader without a background in statistics will understand: The explanations are often more allusions to than descriptions of the innovations discussed. Having an interest in the field, though, the book humanises a lot of the great names in statistics.

Honestly, I am lukewarm on this book. It was interesting, and the subject matter is so impactful, I wanted to love it.However, I found it lacking both in math (some times you just need math - i get that the author wanted to make it accessible to everyone, but, sometimes the concepts just weren't clear enough without), and in narrative structure. The book jumped around a little bit, and occasionally it was challenging to follow a thread.The author's love for the subject matter and the subjects was quite clear, though.

I ate through this book like a fever - a particularly terminal one. Weird to think that it is only now that I'm associating a face, a life, to the names that I continuously had to deal with in my undergraduate years and now while I approach the end of my masters. Neyman being afraid of Fisher's criticisms, Egon Pearson establishing his own journal for fear of angering his father Karl by working with Neyman on Fisher's idea of the likelihood function and developing the theory of hypothesis testing. Fisher moving from being the lowly genius marked by its then tyrant Karl Pearson into being its own feared but at the same time revered tyrant.I did find problems in Salsburg's unwillingness to invoke even a single line of mathematical complexity into the book, which results in him trailing off into other topics just when his discussion of a particular development hits full stride. But alas, this is a book written for the nonmathematicians, and to that end, certain tradeoffs must be made. It certainly did not affect my enjoyment of the book. A week from starting it and I come out with a relived appreciation for the field I've committed myself into, and to the men and women who built its foundations. This is a book that I highly recommend for young statisticians, and those who are considering statistics as a prospective field of study.

The lives of the great 20th Century statisticians! What could be more engrossing than a hagiography of bean counters?I read this book because I have a vague interest in statistics, but a very poor foundation for grappling with the actual math. If I've taken away an appreciation for the concepts that have driven the remarkable "statistical revolution" that I, like most readers, was not aware that we have just experienced, it's at an entirely subconscious level. I'm sure I can't now expound wisely on the usefulness and pitfalls of P-values, or explain non-Bayesian vs. Bayesian approaches. Thanks to this surprisingly readable, if appropriately non-exciting history, perhaps I'll be able to get a little traction next time I try to tread that territory.To Salsburg's credit, it was not actually boring, given that the "action" described was the presentation of papers at conventions, or the inclusion of names in bibliographies. I've developed a pretty high tolerance for the prosaic, however, so no promises.Recommended audience: students of statistics who want to know more about their heroes; people like me who will pick up anything from the "light science" shelf in the library and, once committed, stick with it out of pride, or for the heck of it.Favorite fact: (spoiler alert) Some of the great advances in modern statistics were made on behalf of the Guinness brewery, in their continuing effort to improve and maintain the consistency of their tasty, tasty beverage.

A seemingly thorough overview of the history of statistics and the various people in it, but there are so many names and characters whizzing by that sometimes the statistics itself is left behind. There are several times where the author mentions an important theory or development, only to give it the barest explanation, or none at all. Understandably this is not a book about statistics itself, and to attempt to satisfactorily explain and prove the broad collection of ideas within it would likely require multiple volumes.  The book at its best in the beginning, before branching off in every which way, when examining the very beginning of the field, with Gosset and Pearson and Fisher. As it continues, and more and more characters are introduced, it becomes difficult to keep track of the landscape, or of a strong logical flow to the arrangement of chapters. For a person already familiar with some of the history of statistics or with the theory itself this may be fine, but for a relative neophytes like myself it makes for a more difficult read.  Despite its flaws, the book is still interesting and coherent enough to be worth the read, though some later chapters are skippable.

This book is an informal history of the development of statistics in the 20th century. The author, who was a statistician in the pharmaceutical industry, had meant many of the statisticians whose work he discusses. It is not a mathematical book, in the sense that not a line of algebra is to be found in it.  The author begins with Karl Pearson in Britain at the begining of the twentieth century, when he took over Francis Galton (cousin of Charles Darwin, promoter of the use of fingerprints in identification, and eugenicist) biometrical (measuring people) laboratory in London. Pearson believed that the aim of science, in a world where the objects of study show ubiquitous numerical variation in the measurement of any trait you care to mention, should be the determination of the smaller number of parameters (numbers like the average, the standard deviation, plus some more obscure ones like symmetry and kurtosis) that describe the distribution of variability of a trait. Pearson's importance was greatly inhanced by his ediotrial control over an important scientific journal, Biometrika  In this journal, Pearson early on published the work of William Gosset, the developer of a most useful statisticial test called the t test, with which one can determine how likely it is that two different samples with different means are in fact different. Gosset had to published under a pen name because his employer, the Guiness brewery, forbade its employees to publish after an unfortunate incident when a brewer gave out some trade secrets.  The next great figure, definitely of the most important statisticians, possibly the most important, and scientists of the 20th century was R. A. Fisher. Fisher developed most of the statistical techniques, such as analysis of variance, that I used 80 years later to analyze, interpret, and design experiments. Fisher combined great mathematical insight with the writing of a book,  Statistical Methods for Research Workers , that showed us lesser mortals how to go about designing and analyzing experiments in a proper manner without worrying us about how these methods worked. Unfortunately for proper mathematicians, he was less good in explaining in his other publications how he derived his methods, and in some cases I gather he never published any derivation. However his unpublished papers show he wasn't making it all up, indeed as late as the 1970s those who examined his unpublished work learned new insights. Gradually other math types filled in or found on their own the detailed proofs.  The other candidate for worlds greatest statistician would be A. N. Kolmogorov, who put probability on a firm mathematical foundation (among many other things). As this work is a necessary condition for statistical application to be valid, this is very important. He was also an important developer of statistical methods. Kolomogorov was a Soviet citizen of astonishingly wide interests (he spent a good deal of time teaching gifted children at a special Moscow school), and great kindness.  The third most important statistician would probably be Jerzy Neyman, a man of Polish antecedents who spent much of his career in the United States. Neyman, along with Egon Pearson (Karl's son) was the developer of the now ubiqutious notion of hypothesis testing. Neyman also developed the concept of a confidence interval. In hypothesis testing you determine how often an experimental outcome, called the null hypothesis, would occur do to chance alone. If this probability is below a small but arbitrary value, one concludes that the null hypothesis is rejected, and that the alternative hypothesis is correct. An example of confidence intervals is when a poll's results state that the president's approval rate is 45%, plus or minus 3%, with 95% confidence. Both of these ideas are controversial as well as very commonly used, in part because their meaning in application (the math is perfectly rigorous)becomes less clear the more you examine them.  Besides the greats, the author covers many other people (including John Tukey, who probably should be included in the list of greats), who made important contributions to statistics. He also covers other techniques than the ones I mentioned above, such as experimental design, non-parametric statistics, computer intensive methods such as the bootstrap, and Bayesian statistics.  The author also brings up the philosophical matters that continue to bedevil statistics, such as the meaning of a probability. The most common approach is the frequentist school, in which a probability is the fraction of total outcomes in which a particular outcome (say winning the lottery divided by the number of tickets you've bought) is observed. There are difficulties with this approach, as there are with alternative Bayesian approaches. I think the author is mistaken in his apparent belief that issue is primarily limited to applications of statistics; I would says that it is problem with all forms of knowledge which depend to some extent on induction, the drawing of conclusions from necessarily limited numbers of experiences.  The book includes a bibliography, including a most helpful annotated section of recommended books that are light on the math. There is also a chronology of developments in statistics.  I enjoyed the book. I found some of the discussions of statistical issues unclear, which I attribute to the author's unwillingness to introduce any mathematical notation in order to avoid scaring off readers. I think a little math at the level of simple algebra, possibly separated from the main text in separate boxes so as not to disturb the flow of the narrative, would have been helpful in this regard.

This book is a wonderful history of statistics. Salsburg does an excellent job of providing a truly human history of the names and methods we have all become so familiar with. This is not, however, a book of mathematical theory. Still, in his conclusion, Salsburg provides a brief overview of the epistemological problems associated with our interpretation of probability, enough so to make me think more about how I sling around P values as a researcher. More than anything, this book made me appreciate how hard it once was to actually calculate statistics, something that computers have certainly made us take for granted. This book should be required reading for first year graduate students in the physical and life sciences.

If you expect a solid overview about the history of statistics, this book is not for you. It's definitely not academic/encyclopedic. Salsburg provides a lot of anecdotes from his personal encounters with prominent statisticians. It is rather a story of statistical revolution as it as happening from its active participant and practitioner who helped to form its trajectory. The book is easy to read and entertaining. I personally enjoyed the chapters on problem solving, i.e. those that described how certain statistical procedures were developed in response to concrete problems one faced (aka Fisher's ANOVA and his crop studies, Student's t-test and his brewing problem, Chester Bliss's probit model as an answer to toxicology problem, etc)

A great book that takes you in a historical and biographical tour, from Pearson's and his skew distributions to Tukey's and his bootstraps (1895 -2000's), in a very fluid, interesting and easy to grasp manner. The final remarks of the book are for me the intellectually most important part of the book. As makes clear the importance of statistics in our every day but remark the problems that statistics face in a philosophical and ultimately scientifical manner.Notes: The book does not go deep into mathematical explanations but requires a deep interest and basic knowledge of statistics from the reader.

The Lady Tasting Tea is an entertaining history of mathematical statistics from its beginnings with the work of Karl Pearson to about the late eighties. More a collection of vignettes about different statisticians than a comprehensive history, the book has its best moments in the anecdotal description of its subjects, often drawing from Salsburg's own experience with them. While the book is written for non-experts, I am wondering how much a reader without a background in statistics will understand: The explanations are often more allusions to than descriptions of the innovations discussed. Having an interest in the field, though, the book humanises a lot of the great names in statistics.

Honestly, I am lukewarm on this book. It was interesting, and the subject matter is so impactful, I wanted to love it.However, I found it lacking both in math (some times you just need math - i get that the author wanted to make it accessible to everyone, but, sometimes the concepts just weren't clear enough without), and in narrative structure. The book jumped around a little bit, and occasionally it was challenging to follow a thread.The author's love for the subject matter and the subjects was quite clear, though.

I ate through this book like a fever - a particularly terminal one. Weird to think that it is only now that I'm associating a face, a life, to the names that I continuously had to deal with in my undergraduate years and now while I approach the end of my masters. Neyman being afraid of Fisher's criticisms, Egon Pearson establishing his own journal for fear of angering his father Karl by working with Neyman on Fisher's idea of the likelihood function and developing the theory of hypothesis testing. Fisher moving from being the lowly genius marked by its then tyrant Karl Pearson into being its own feared but at the same time revered tyrant.I did find problems in Salsburg's unwillingness to invoke even a single line of mathematical complexity into the book, which results in him trailing off into other topics just when his discussion of a particular development hits full stride. But alas, this is a book written for the nonmathematicians, and to that end, certain tradeoffs must be made. It certainly did not affect my enjoyment of the book. A week from starting it and I come out with a relived appreciation for the field I've committed myself into, and to the men and women who built its foundations. This is a book that I highly recommend for young statisticians, and those who are considering statistics as a prospective field of study.

The lives of the great 20th Century statisticians! What could be more engrossing than a hagiography of bean counters?I read this book because I have a vague interest in statistics, but a very poor foundation for grappling with the actual math. If I've taken away an appreciation for the concepts that have driven the remarkable "statistical revolution" that I, like most readers, was not aware that we have just experienced, it's at an entirely subconscious level. I'm sure I can't now expound wisely on the usefulness and pitfalls of P-values, or explain non-Bayesian vs. Bayesian approaches. Thanks to this surprisingly readable, if appropriately non-exciting history, perhaps I'll be able to get a little traction next time I try to tread that territory.To Salsburg's credit, it was not actually boring, given that the "action" described was the presentation of papers at conventions, or the inclusion of names in bibliographies. I've developed a pretty high tolerance for the prosaic, however, so no promises.Recommended audience: students of statistics who want to know more about their heroes; people like me who will pick up anything from the "light science" shelf in the library and, once committed, stick with it out of pride, or for the heck of it.Favorite fact: (spoiler alert) Some of the great advances in modern statistics were made on behalf of the Guinness brewery, in their continuing effort to improve and maintain the consistency of their tasty, tasty beverage.

A seemingly thorough overview of the history of statistics and the various people in it, but there are so many names and characters whizzing by that sometimes the statistics itself is left behind. There are several times where the author mentions an important theory or development, only to give it the barest explanation, or none at all. Understandably this is not a book about statistics itself, and to attempt to satisfactorily explain and prove the broad collection of ideas within it would likely require multiple volumes.  The book at its best in the beginning, before branching off in every which way, when examining the very beginning of the field, with Gosset and Pearson and Fisher. As it continues, and more and more characters are introduced, it becomes difficult to keep track of the landscape, or of a strong logical flow to the arrangement of chapters. For a person already familiar with some of the history of statistics or with the theory itself this may be fine, but for a relative neophytes like myself it makes for a more difficult read.  Despite its flaws, the book is still interesting and coherent enough to be worth the read, though some later chapters are skippable.

This book is an informal history of the development of statistics in the 20th century. The author, who was a statistician in the pharmaceutical industry, had meant many of the statisticians whose work he discusses. It is not a mathematical book, in the sense that not a line of algebra is to be found in it.  The author begins with Karl Pearson in Britain at the begining of the twentieth century, when he took over Francis Galton (cousin of Charles Darwin, promoter of the use of fingerprints in identification, and eugenicist) biometrical (measuring people) laboratory in London. Pearson believed that the aim of science, in a world where the objects of study show ubiquitous numerical variation in the measurement of any trait you care to mention, should be the determination of the smaller number of parameters (numbers like the average, the standard deviation, plus some more obscure ones like symmetry and kurtosis) that describe the distribution of variability of a trait. Pearson's importance was greatly inhanced by his ediotrial control over an important scientific journal, Biometrika  In this journal, Pearson early on published the work of William Gosset, the developer of a most useful statisticial test called the t test, with which one can determine how likely it is that two different samples with different means are in fact different. Gosset had to published under a pen name because his employer, the Guiness brewery, forbade its employees to publish after an unfortunate incident when a brewer gave out some trade secrets.  The next great figure, definitely of the most important statisticians, possibly the most important, and scientists of the 20th century was R. A. Fisher. Fisher developed most of the statistical techniques, such as analysis of variance, that I used 80 years later to analyze, interpret, and design experiments. Fisher combined great mathematical insight with the writing of a book,  Statistical Methods for Research Workers , that showed us lesser mortals how to go about designing and analyzing experiments in a proper manner without worrying us about how these methods worked. Unfortunately for proper mathematicians, he was less good in explaining in his other publications how he derived his methods, and in some cases I gather he never published any derivation. However his unpublished papers show he wasn't making it all up, indeed as late as the 1970s those who examined his unpublished work learned new insights. Gradually other math types filled in or found on their own the detailed proofs.  The other candidate for worlds greatest statistician would be A. N. Kolmogorov, who put probability on a firm mathematical foundation (among many other things). As this work is a necessary condition for statistical application to be valid, this is very important. He was also an important developer of statistical methods. Kolomogorov was a Soviet citizen of astonishingly wide interests (he spent a good deal of time teaching gifted children at a special Moscow school), and great kindness.  The third most important statistician would probably be Jerzy Neyman, a man of Polish antecedents who spent much of his career in the United States. Neyman, along with Egon Pearson (Karl's son) was the developer of the now ubiqutious notion of hypothesis testing. Neyman also developed the concept of a confidence interval. In hypothesis testing you determine how often an experimental outcome, called the null hypothesis, would occur do to chance alone. If this probability is below a small but arbitrary value, one concludes that the null hypothesis is rejected, and that the alternative hypothesis is correct. An example of confidence intervals is when a poll's results state that the president's approval rate is 45%, plus or minus 3%, with 95% confidence. Both of these ideas are controversial as well as very commonly used, in part because their meaning in application (the math is perfectly rigorous)becomes less clear the more you examine them.  Besides the greats, the author covers many other people (including John Tukey, who probably should be included in the list of greats), who made important contributions to statistics. He also covers other techniques than the ones I mentioned above, such as experimental design, non-parametric statistics, computer intensive methods such as the bootstrap, and Bayesian statistics.  The author also brings up the philosophical matters that continue to bedevil statistics, such as the meaning of a probability. The most common approach is the frequentist school, in which a probability is the fraction of total outcomes in which a particular outcome (say winning the lottery divided by the number of tickets you've bought) is observed. There are difficulties with this approach, as there are with alternative Bayesian approaches. I think the author is mistaken in his apparent belief that issue is primarily limited to applications of statistics; I would says that it is problem with all forms of knowledge which depend to some extent on induction, the drawing of conclusions from necessarily limited numbers of experiences.  The book includes a bibliography, including a most helpful annotated section of recommended books that are light on the math. There is also a chronology of developments in statistics.  I enjoyed the book. I found some of the discussions of statistical issues unclear, which I attribute to the author's unwillingness to introduce any mathematical notation in order to avoid scaring off readers. I think a little math at the level of simple algebra, possibly separated from the main text in separate boxes so as not to disturb the flow of the narrative, would have been helpful in this regard.

This book is a wonderful history of statistics. Salsburg does an excellent job of providing a truly human history of the names and methods we have all become so familiar with. This is not, however, a book of mathematical theory. Still, in his conclusion, Salsburg provides a brief overview of the epistemological problems associated with our interpretation of probability, enough so to make me think more about how I sling around P values as a researcher. More than anything, this book made me appreciate how hard it once was to actually calculate statistics, something that computers have certainly made us take for granted. This book should be required reading for first year graduate students in the physical and life sciences.

If you expect a solid overview about the history of statistics, this book is not for you. It's definitely not academic/encyclopedic. Salsburg provides a lot of anecdotes from his personal encounters with prominent statisticians. It is rather a story of statistical revolution as it as happening from its active participant and practitioner who helped to form its trajectory. The book is easy to read and entertaining. I personally enjoyed the chapters on problem solving, i.e. those that described how certain statistical procedures were developed in response to concrete problems one faced (aka Fisher's ANOVA and his crop studies, Student's t-test and his brewing problem, Chester Bliss's probit model as an answer to toxicology problem, etc)

A great book that takes you in a historical and biographical tour, from Pearson's and his skew distributions to Tukey's and his bootstraps (1895 -2000's), in a very fluid, interesting and easy to grasp manner. The final remarks of the book are for me the intellectually most important part of the book. As makes clear the importance of statistics in our every day but remark the problems that statistics face in a philosophical and ultimately scientifical manner.Notes: The book does not go deep into mathematical explanations but requires a deep interest and basic knowledge of statistics from the reader.

The Lady Tasting Tea is an entertaining history of mathematical statistics from its beginnings with the work of Karl Pearson to about the late eighties. More a collection of vignettes about different statisticians than a comprehensive history, the book has its best moments in the anecdotal description of its subjects, often drawing from Salsburg's own experience with them. While the book is written for non-experts, I am wondering how much a reader without a background in statistics will understand: The explanations are often more allusions to than descriptions of the innovations discussed. Having an interest in the field, though, the book humanises a lot of the great names in statistics.

Honestly, I am lukewarm on this book. It was interesting, and the subject matter is so impactful, I wanted to love it.However, I found it lacking both in math (some times you just need math - i get that the author wanted to make it accessible to everyone, but, sometimes the concepts just weren't clear enough without), and in narrative structure. The book jumped around a little bit, and occasionally it was challenging to follow a thread.The author's love for the subject matter and the subjects was quite clear, though.

Superb overview of the history, innovators, and key players in the foundation and modernization of statistics. A really fun book, though it should be supplemented with a basic technical book with some of the maths (since this book avoids equations and sticks the narratives).
Learn what statistical geniuses were assholes!
I enjoyed to know some background about those statisticians like Fisher, Neyman, et al. It seems it helps to have undergone a few courses of statistics in order to enjoy this book more.
